div.p: I'm Roo Reynolds and I'm a product manager at GDS. OPG stands for Office of the
Public Guardian, and that's one of the executive bodies within the ministry of justice. The
project that we're working with them on is the lasting power of attorney. So if somebody's
going to lose mental capacity and they want to give somebody else power over their life,
their financial affairs, and indeed all parts of their life, then they need to have that
person be given the power of attorney. In the current system, that's a paper form
and it requires you to enter your name and your address multiple times on the same paper
form. It's very easy to get it wrong; even lawyers are not perfect when it comes to filling
in these sorts of things, and it's often done with the help of a solicitor or some
other professional. Even they will frequently make mistakes, so it's a painful process
to go through at what could be a difficult time in your life.
We've been working with MOJ to think about a product and build a prototype of a product
that would allow somebody to grant the lasting power of attorney to someone else digitally.
ERTP stands for electoral registration transformation programme. It's a programme within government
run at the moment by the cabinet office. The idea is to move from a system of household
registration. So when you come to register to vote, it's the head of the household
that fills it in in this very kind of antiquated way. So the government wants to do two things;
we want to increase the accuracy of the electoral register, but also the completeness, and those
two goals go hand-in-hand. We can often start with a pretty good idea
of what the user needs for what a system will be. But the sooner you can start testing that
theory by putting something that works in front of a group of users and hopefully lots
of different sorts of users, then you can validate that the user needs are actually
useful to you and they're actually the things that are going to make the product better.
It can often mean starting small and then building gradually, and not always knowing
at the beginning what you're going to end up building at the end. So it's quite good
fun.
